nodes.bodyText: So this avoids the copy constructor from allocating the object. Nice. Since this is zero-size, would it be even better to share a single copy cross-instance?
It's already the case that there will be a single copy since the constructors are private and all instances derive from DEFAULT.

I don't think we want to "cheat" with these benchmarks. Most users will pay these same costs.
If we really wanted to optimize this, we would have a single pre-created ByteString and use it to build a new one of the needed size. That would avoid allocating/copying any of the data. But then it is really a lie.

Sure I can revert it. I just thought it might help to isolate the actual grpc parts within the benchmarks, assuming that they're intended more for relative measurements than simulating a particular real-world use case.
Oh, interesting. I didn't realize IdentityHashMap avoided the Map.Entries.
Can do the same for CronetClientTransport.

What changed here? It looks the same. The old version grabbed a variable a few more times, but not only is the variable non-volatile, it's even final. So I can't believe it would actually make any difference.
I agree it's unlikely to make much/any difference especially here, but seems cleaner and good general practice. I.e. in theory less pointer chasing in the loop. Or could be my OCD.

I don't think I agree with "good general practice." I expect the optimizer to do loop invariant hoisting. For simple cases like this I'd put it in the same category as 'optimizing' /2 with >>1 or simplifying 1 + 2 to 3. But this isn't even that hot of a loop. With reasonably-sized buffers, it seems impossible to ever notice this optimization, even if we assume the processor isn't faster executing the later occurrences or the interpreter was being used.
The "cleaner" part for me was combining buffers.add() and the remove() onto the same line. But the original author could have done that and actively chose not to. But adding otherBuffers actually the change overall less clean to my eyes. In any case the original code seems reasonable as-is, so it seems best not to touch it.

Sure, I'll revert it! Yes the "cleanliness" is probably subjective, I have a general preference for minimizing indirections, other things being equal (regardless of perf implications). I don't quite agree that it's in the same category as >>1, 1 + 2 -> 3 since those have a more obvious readability tradeoff.

I was not a fan of the previous behavior. I prefer an approach like this... although this may not provide any benefit. Since execute() didn't leak the reference to op, I'd expect op to be allocated on the stack. Although maybe the interface being called messes things up (since an op could leak a reference to itself when called). I'd be willing to take this anyway.
Name this as one, since it is not truly immutable.

It's unclear if this change improves or worsens performance. Now the type of the return value changes, so the JIT will not optimize the calling code as much. On the other hand, there is less indirection when length is present in a single buffer.
We use AssertionError for impossible internally-guaranteed conditions.

Don't know if we care, but we could have a NonThrowingReadOperation that extends this interface and doesn't have throws IOException. executeNoThrow() could then have that as a parameter. That would preserve the checked exception checking.
I may not completely follow, but I don't see that this would buy much. Unless we wanted to also duplicate the execute() method contents which wouldn't be ideal.

No need to duplicate execute(). execute() and executeNoThrow() would work as you have it here. The difference is that executeNoThrow() could only be called with a ReadOperation that actually doesn't throw IOExceptions.
You might want to clean up the now-unnecessary finals. Not a big deal.
Somewhere the relationship between value and the returned int needs to be mentioned, since that might be surprising and doesn't "jump out" obviously in the code.
FWIW, this allocation should exist on the stack.

FWIW, this allocation should exist on the stack.

What do you mean by "this allocation"?
ByteBuffer.wrap() creates a new object.
